transcript.speaker: Harsh Bansal
transcript.text: So the agenda for this meeting is that this is our daily stand up call

transcript.speaker: Harsh Bansal
transcript.text: and we'll be discussing what kind of task each one

transcript.speaker: Harsh Bansal
transcript.text: person in the team has done. So let's get started.

transcript.speaker: Harsh Bansal
transcript.text: So first, talking about Sam. Sam finished forty tasks

transcript.speaker: Harsh Bansal
transcript.text: in the last week.

transcript.speaker: Harsh Bansal
transcript.text: And all almost all the tasks were small ones that

transcript.speaker: Harsh Bansal
transcript.text: is why this number is so large. But he was very

transcript.speaker: Harsh Bansal
transcript.text: excited about the work, and he

transcript.speaker: Harsh Bansal
transcript.text: enjoyed doing it and also added his own touch to the work so that

transcript.speaker: Harsh Bansal
transcript.text: it looks more impactful.

transcript.speaker: Harsh Bansal
transcript.text: Then coming to our second person, Robert. Robert,

transcript.speaker: Harsh Bansal
transcript.text: finished around twenty five tasks in which two were very, very major tasks.

transcript.speaker: Harsh Bansal
transcript.text: So he focused on them more, and there were bugs in his remaining twenty

transcript.speaker: Harsh Bansal
transcript.text: three tasks. But he was still able to manage

transcript.speaker: Harsh Bansal
transcript.text: fixing them and ensure that the production had lowest amount of downtime.

transcript.speaker: Harsh Bansal
transcript.text: Coming to

transcript.speaker: Harsh Bansal
transcript.text: okay. Coming to GK. GK was focused mostly on his

transcript.speaker: Harsh Bansal
transcript.text: own work rather than the company's work, but yet he was able to

transcript.speaker: Harsh Bansal
transcript.text: do around fifteen tasks in the last week.

transcript.speaker: Harsh Bansal
transcript.text: Almost all of them were very important ones, and so his

transcript.speaker: Harsh Bansal
transcript.text: contribution may be noted specifically

transcript.speaker: Harsh Bansal
transcript.text: because despite his own work in his personal life,

transcript.speaker: Harsh Bansal
transcript.text: he was able to help us with those fifteen tasks

transcript.speaker: Harsh Bansal
transcript.text: There was a major bug in one of his codes where

transcript.speaker: Harsh Bansal
transcript.text: we were trying to take a log on an item that was already logged.

transcript.speaker: Harsh Bansal
transcript.text: And so this broke our systems for around thirty minutes.

transcript.speaker: Harsh Bansal
transcript.text: And CPU usage went up to ninety five percent

transcript.speaker: Harsh Bansal
transcript.text: causing five pagers to come while he was

transcript.speaker: Harsh Bansal
transcript.text: away, and so someone else had to take care of it.

transcript.speaker: Harsh Bansal
transcript.text: And we need to take note of this that this does not happen again and again.

transcript.speaker: Harsh Bansal
transcript.text: Also, guys, just to discuss another major update,

transcript.speaker: Harsh Bansal
transcript.text: So in the last meeting, we

transcript.speaker: Harsh Bansal
transcript.text: were told that our team has been performing really well, but the number of

transcript.speaker: Harsh Bansal
transcript.text: holidays that we take are too much.

transcript.speaker: Harsh Bansal
transcript.text: And though I try to defend to my best capabilities that

transcript.speaker: Harsh Bansal
transcript.text: my team is not taking too many holidays, it is just that we work

transcript.speaker: Harsh Bansal
transcript.text: too much, and so we have to take a little bit of rest. But still,

transcript.speaker: Harsh Bansal
transcript.text: we should try to ensure that this does not get noticed. If we are planning to take

transcript.speaker: Harsh Bansal
transcript.text: more than more than what we are supposed to in terms of lease,

transcript.speaker: Harsh Bansal
transcript.text: then either we should take them silently or

transcript.speaker: Harsh Bansal
transcript.text: I mean, just try to take less leaves

transcript.speaker: Harsh Bansal
transcript.text: and take rest in the office itself. I know this is

transcript.speaker: Harsh Bansal
transcript.text: something that I should not be saying, but at least we should try to manage this.

summary: This was a daily stand-up meeting where team members reported on their tasks from the past week. Sam completed 40 small tasks, adding personal touches to enhance their impact. Robert finished 25 tasks, including two major ones, and managed bugs in the remaining tasks, ensuring minimal production downtime. GK completed 15 important tasks, despite focusing on personal work, and his contributions were noted. A major bug was identified in GK's code, causing a 30-minute system outage and high CPU usage, which required another team member to handle. The meeting also addressed the issue of excessive holidays taken by the team, with a directive to be more discreet about taking time off to avoid negative attention.
key_points: Robert completed approximately 25 tasks, with a focus on two major ones, and managed bugs effectively to minimize production downtime.
GK completed around 15 important tasks despite personal commitments, though a major bug in his code caused a 30-minute system outage and high CPU usage.
A critical bug related to logging an already logged item caused a system breakdown for 30 minutes, leading to high CPU usage and pager alerts.
There's a need to prevent recurrence of the system outage issue caused by GK's code.
The team's holiday usage was flagged as high in the previous meeting, and there's a need to manage this perception or actual usage to avoid negative attention.

action_items.description: Ensure that the major bug in GK's code (logging an item that was already logged) does not happen again.
Ensure the major bug in GK's code (logging an already logged item) does not happen again.
Monitor and manage team holiday usage to avoid negative attention.
